channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: I.C.C. Judges Denounce Effect of Trump’s Sanctions
item.description: President Trump’s retaliation against top officials at the International Criminal Court has shut them out of American services and made even routine daily tasks a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.media:credit: Peter Dejong/Associated Press
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague. U.S. sanctions come at a time when the court is investigating claims of atrocities in Afghanistan, Libya, Myanmar, Sudan, Ukraine and Venezuela, as well as Gaza.

item.title: Russia Says It Used Nuclear-Capable Missile to Strike Western Ukraine
item.description: The attack seemed intended to send a message to Europe as it strongly backs Kyiv in the peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage to an apartment building in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, after a presumed drone strike on Friday.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Vows to ‘Not Back Down’ as Protests Swell
item.description: After days of fierce protest, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei accused protesters of trying to “please” President Trump. Iranian authorities signaled further crackdowns on the demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Office Of The Iranian Supreme Leader, via Reuters
item.media:description: A picture made available by the office of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuela Updates: Trump’s Push to Invest in Venezuela Gets a Tepid Response From Oil Executives
item.description: Meeting with leaders of Exxon Mobil, Chevron and other oil companies, the president said he wanted the industry to invest $100 billion in rebuilding the infrastructure in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: How an Abrupt Call Between Trump and Colombia’s President Averted a Crisis
item.description: President Gustavo Petro said that the new tone between the leaders was “friendly,” but he also resurfaced his deep disagreements with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia at the Presidential Palace in Bogotá, on Thursday, during an interview with The New York Times.

item.title: Yemeni Separatists Say They Are Disbanding, but Move Is in Dispute
item.description: A delegation from the Southern Transitional Council in Riyadh announced its dissolution, but members abroad rejected the news amid fears it was not voluntary.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar, Saeed Al-Batati and Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Fawaz Salman/Reuters
item.media:description: Soldiers on Thursday in Aden, Yemen, outside the headquarters of the Southern Transitional Council, a separatist group that has sought to create an independent state in Yemen’s south.

item.title: Inside Myanmar’s Gilded Capital, Empty Streets and Moldy Corners
item.description: Myanmar’s junta created a capital to withstand an invasion. Now, the military struggles to project an image of control over a crumbling nation.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: An empty road in front of decommissioned tanks at the Defense Services Museum complex in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, the day after a vote in December.

item.title: Runway Wall Caused All the Deaths in 2024 South Korean Plane Crash, Report Says
item.description: A computer simulation ordered by the government showed that everyone on board would have survived if the concrete berm had been made of materials that easily broke apart.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The concrete wall at the end of the runway that the Jeju Air plane hit at Muan International Airport in 2024. A computer simulation concluded that everyone would have survived if it had been made of breakable materials.

item.title: What to Know About the Protests in Iran
item.description: Galloping inflation, a currency crisis and anger at the regime have fueled demonstrations across the country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Wana News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state media showing shops in Tehran on Dec. 30 that were closed after protests.

item.title: What Is the Oreshnik Ballistic Missile Russia Used in a Strike on Ukraine?
item.description: The attack was just the second time that Moscow had launched the nuclear-capable intermediate-range ballistic weapon.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin is seen on a screen at a military parade on Victory Day in Moscow in 2024.

item.title: Prosecutor Asks for Owner of Swiss Bar Hit by Deadly Fire to Be Detained
item.description: The request came after hours of questioning of the bar’s co-owners. Some 40 people died in the fire that broke out during a New Year’s celebration.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Umit Bektas/Reuters
item.media:description: Jacques and Jessica Moretti, the owners of the Swiss bar that burned in a deadly fire last week, in Sion, Switzerland, on Friday.

item.title: Why Russian Tourists Are Flocking to Southern China’s Beaches
item.description: Russians find a refuge on the beaches of Sanya from sanctions and “sideways looks,” toasting the New Year beside a Chinese nuclear submarine base.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié

item.title: Lebanon Claims Progress in Disarming Militant Groups Like Hezbollah
item.description: The military said it had completed the first phase of a plan to demilitarize armed groups as fears grew that Israel was preparing a new offensive against Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Hezbollah at the funeral for three people killed in an Israeli military attack in July.

item.title: Venezuela Leaders Free Political Prisoners in a Sign of Possible Change
item.description: The interim government released some prisoners under pressure from the Trump administration, even as it continued arrests and crackdowns elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Emma Bubola, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Atali Cabrejo waits for the release of her son, Juan Jose Freites, outside El Helicoide prison in Caracas, Venezuela, on Thursday.

item.title: Why Cambodia Handed Over a Man Accused of Stealing Billions in Crypto Scam
item.description: Experts say the scam industry has become a pillar of Cambodia’s economy, but it is under pressure from other countries to crack down.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A building in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, listed on the website of Prince Holding Group as its headquarters, on Thursday. The company has been accused by U.S. prosecutors of operating cyberscams.

item.title: After President’s Capture, U.S. and Venezuela Explore Restoring Diplomatic Ties
item.description: The move embodied the contradictions and fast-changing nature of the two countries’ relationship.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2019.

item.title: Trump Urges Oil Companies to Speed Work in Venezuela
item.description: The president met with executives on a day when the U.S. seized another tanker carrying Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Eric Schmitt and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at a meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Iran Convulsed in Second Night of Nationwide Protests
item.description: Large marches against the government occurred despite an internet blackout and threats of a severe crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators marched in Tehran in an image taken from a social media post that was shared on Thursday.

item.title: Mohammed Harbi, Who Rewrote Algeria’s History, Dies at 92
item.description: He was an official in the revolutionary government, then, after the country won independence from France, was imprisoned and eventually wrote from exile.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Outside Prisons in Caracas, Venezuelans Anxiously Await Release of More Political Detainees
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government said it would release an “important number” of imprisoned people, but only nine have been confirmed freed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members awaiting the release of prisoners outside El Helicoide, a notorious prison in the center of Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Take Greenland ‘the Hard Way’
item.description: The president continued to advance an imperialist vision of American foreign policy, where the U.S. can dominate neighboring countries “whether they like it or not.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at the meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Hessy Levinsons Taft, Jewish Baby on Cover of Nazi Magazine, Dies at 91
item.description: Without her parents’ knowledge, her portrait was entered as a prank in a contest in 1935 to represent the ideal Aryan infant — and she won.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: A Look at Iran’s Antigovernment Protests
item.description: Protests have rocked Iran in recent weeks, and the country’s supreme leader has threatened to escalate a crackdown on demonstrators. Erika Solomon, our bureau chief for Iran and Iraq, discusses what’s fueling the protests with our senior writer Katrin Bennhold.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Katrin Bennhold, Christina Thornell, Christina Shaman, Parin Behrooz and Sanjana Varghese

item.title: An Up-Close Look at the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: From an icebreaker sailing near the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica, our photographer has captured the many faces of the ice.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: With Missile Strike on Ukraine, Putin Delivers a Warning to Europe
item.description: A nuclear-capable missile fired into Ukraine near Poland sent a message to Europe days after its leaders agreed to postwar security guarantees, Russian analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage to an apartment building in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, after a strike on Friday.

item.title: What Is El Helicoide, the Infamous Torture Prison in Venezuela?
item.description: As Venezuela’s interim authorities began to release political prisoners, some of their families raced to the notorious prison that symbolized Nicolás Maduro’s authoritarian rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Sulbarán and James Wagner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: El Helicoide seen in Caracas on Thursday. It was first conceived as a futuristic mall before being repurposed to hold prisoners.

item.title: Freed Venezuelan Political Prisoner Called Maduro’s 2024 Victory a Fraud to His Face
item.description: Enrique Márquez, a centrist opposition lawmaker, refused to rubber-stamp the government’s dubious election results in front of the entire nation.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Federico Parra/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The former Venezuelan presidential candidate Enrique Márquez looking at a voting record during a news conference in Caracas in 2024.

item.title: U.S. Boards Another Tanker Carrying Venezuelan Oil
item.description: The tanker, the Olina, is the fifth to be boarded or seized by U.S. forces in recent weeks as part of an effort to control Venezuela’s oil exports.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Maryorin Mendez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Silhouettes of children carrying a net at a fishing pier while in the background a crude oil tanker is docking in Venezuela’s Maracaibo Lake on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Leo Rebukes a Spreading Global ‘Zeal for War’
item.description: The pontiff used an annual address to ambassadors to the Vatican to condemn countries that prioritized violence over diplomacy to achieve their goals.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Filippo Monteforte/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV in Vatican City on Thursday. On Friday he urged nations to commit to work together to follow international laws.

item.title: Landfill Collapse in Philippines Leaves 4 Dead and Dozens Missing
item.description: A garbage mound outside Cebu City in the central Philippines collapsed on Thursday. Rescuers were searching for 34 missing people, including some trapped under the debris.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Jacqueline Hernandez/Associated Press
item.media:description: The huge mound of garbage at a waste facility in Binaliw in the Philippines on Friday, the day after it collapsed.

item.title: Trump Indicates He Will Meet Venezuela’s Machado After Offer to Give Him Her Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: President Trump indicated that he would meet the Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado. Last year, she won the Nobel Peace Prize, an award he covets.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, at an election rally in Caracas in 2024.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

item.title: In Venezuela, Trump Revives ‘Gunboat Diplomacy.’ What Is It?
item.description: The U.S. campaign in Venezuela has drawn from a centuries-old playbook employing naval force — but added some new elements, too.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: A U.S. Navy vessel off the coast of Puerto Rico last month. The U.S. Navy has been part of an American military buildup in the Caribbean.

item.title: Venezuelans Decry Civilian Casualties. Pentagon Says It’s Unaware of Any.
item.description: For all Venezuelans, the nighttime raid opened a period of deep uncertainty. For the families of those killed, it meant the grim task of burying their relatives.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends and family at the burial of Rosa Elena González, 80, who was killed during the U.S. raid to capture Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Once Again, a Newfoundland Town Rescues Stranded Passengers
item.description: After 9/11, Gander took in thousands of people whose flights were diverted. History repeated on a smaller scale this week.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The airport in Gander, Newfoundland, where three flights were diverted this week for bad weather, stranding travelers.

item.title: Ukraine Awards Major Lithium Project to Investors With Links to Trump
item.description: Ronald S. Lauder, a billionaire friend of Mr. Trump, is among the investors. The move comes as the Trump administration looks for investment opportunities in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ronald S. Lauder is one of the investors who won the bid to mine lithium deposits in Ukraine. He has known President Trump since college.

item.title: U.S. Navy Is Chasing Several Oil Tankers in the Atlantic
item.description: A mass departure by sanctioned tankers, some switching to Russian flags, has triggered a fresh effort by the United States to pursue Venezuelan oil shipments at sea.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Riley Mellen and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: U.S. Southern Command
item.media:description: An image from video released by the U.S. military purporting to show the seizure of the oil tanker M Sophia in the Caribbean on Wednesday.

item.title: Rocío San Miguel, Venezuelan Political Prisoner, Was Among Those Released
item.description: Ms. San Miguel’s arrest in 2024 raised fears that Venezuela had entered a new era of repression.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators demanding the release of Rocío San Miguel, one of Venezuela’s most prominent political prisoners, at a rally held in Madrid, last year.

item.title: Russian Propaganda Ramps Up After U.S. Raid in Venezuela
item.description: A network of websites known as “Portal Kombat” is spreading messages about U.S. military hardware, according to tracking firms.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Ramil Sitdikov/Reuters
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow. Russia and Venezuela have had a close diplomatic relationship, and Moscow is keen to retain those ties.

item.title: An Interview With Donald Trump
item.description: The president spoke to The New York Times about Venezuela and his power on the world stage.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking to New York Times reporters on Wednesday.

item.title: Fact-Checking Trump’s Justifications for the Venezuela Operation
item.description: The president has repeatedly tied Venezuela to drug overdose deaths, claimed the Maduro regime sent an influx of criminal migrants and accused the country of stealing American oil.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at a news conference on Saturday at Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: Climate Change Has Turned Greenland Into a Target for Trump
item.description: A warming planet has opened up new shipping routes and turned Greenland into a geostrategic asset for the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: A partially frozen sea just outside Nuuk, Greenland, last year.

item.title: Macron tells ambassadors that the world has become ‘unhinged.’
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Michel Euler
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris on Thursday. He told a group of global ambassadors that rules around the world had been discarded.

item.title: Iran Is Cut Off From Internet as Protests Calling for Regime Change Intensify
item.description: As protests swelled around the country, Iran’s internet was shut down, and the heads of its judiciary and its security services warned of a harsh response amid calls for “freedom, freedom.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Pranav Baskar and Sanam Mahoozi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Kamran/Middle East Images, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People blocked a street during a protest in Kermanshah, Iran, on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Addresses Venezuela, Greenland and Presidential Power in New York Times Interview
item.description: On topic after topic, President Trump made clear that he would be the arbiter of any limits to his authorities, not international law or treaties.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Three Reported Missing in Australia as Fires Rage in ‘Catastrophic’ Conditions
item.description: The country is in the midst of a record-breaking heat wave, with temperatures well above 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Multiple bush fires were burning in the state of Victoria.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Saeed Khan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Many places around Australia have recorded their highest temperatures since 2020 this week.

item.title: The Icebreaker Araon Stops Near the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Less than a day after arriving at the ice, we are already up close and personal with the fastest-melting glacier in Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: French Researcher and Russian Basketball Player Released in a Prisoner Swap
item.description: Laurent Vinatier, a French citizen and researcher, was freed in exchange for the release of Daniil Kasatkin, a Russian basketball player.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:credit: Alexander Nemenov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The French researcher Laurent Vinatier in court in Moscow in 2024.

item.title: NASA Will Bring I.S.S. Astronauts Home Early After Medical Issue
item.description: After canceling a spacewalk planned for Thursday, the space agency’s administrator said it was erring on the side of caution and bringing a crew of four home in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Steve Nesius/Reuters

item.title: Rubio Says He’ll Discuss Greenland With Danish Officials Next Week
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio told reporters he would speak with the officials after days of mounting threats from the Trump administration to take Greenland, a semiautonomous Danish territory.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said he would meet with Danish officials next week to discuss the future of Greenland.

item.title: Saudi Official Accuses U.A.E. of Helping Yemeni Separatist to Escape
item.description: Aidarous al-Zubaidi is wanted on treason charges in Yemen after he led a lightning military offensive that escalated a bitter feud between the Emirates and Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Fawaz Salman/Reuters
item.media:description: An image of Aidarous al-Zubaidi, leader of the Southern Transitional Council, in Aden, Yemen on Wednesday. The group has been pushing for an independent state in southern Yemen, with Emirati backing.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Robert Jimison

item.title: Colombia’s President Feared a U.S. Attack. Then Trump Called.
item.description: The conversation appeared to defuse a crisis that erupted after President Trump said military action against Colombia “sounds good.” President Gustavo Petro spoke to The New York Times just before the call.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Max Bearak and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia during an interview with The New York Times in Cartagena on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Strikes Knock Out Power in Dnipro Region of Ukraine
item.description: The Ukrainian authorities urged residents in the Dnipropetrovsk region to stock up on water as crews raced to restore service.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: A power blackout in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Wednesday after strikes. Ukraine’s grid operator said power to the region was largely restored on Thursday, but the neighboring Dnipropetrovsk region was still being affected.

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Oversight of Venezuela Could Last for Years
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times on Wednesday, President Trump said “only time will tell” when it comes to how long the United States aims to control the country.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office with Vice President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Wednesday.

item.title: Most Venezuelans Struggle to Pay for Food, Poll Shows
item.description: A new Gallup survey found that more than half of Venezuelans reported struggling to afford food last year, with economic hardship reaching even the wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: At a street market in Caracas, the capital of Venezuela, in October.

item.title: When It Comes to Russia, Trump Navigates Conflicting Goals
item.description: President Trump’s efforts to court President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia are rife with contradictions about stability and displays of American power.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin in Alaska last August. Mr. Trump’s focus on strength has magnified tensions with Russia in regions like Latin America, where Mr. Putin has sought to extend his influence

item.title: Hoisting Russian Flags, ‘Shadow Fleet’ Edges Into the Light
item.description: The Marinera, which was seized by the U.S., isn’t the only ship from the “shadow fleet” of oil tankers to switch lately to a Russian identity, seeking protection.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Michael Schwirtz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Vesa Moilanen/Lehtikuva, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Eagle S, an oil tanker, last January after Finnish commandos commandeered it over suspicions that it had deliberately cut vital undersea cables. The authorities said the ship appeared to belong to Russia’s shadow fleet.
